Need good hiking or running shoes if you want to climb up on some of the boulders. In and out of the forest with some sunny spots along the way. Good for a morning or afternoon activity as it's not too long.", 'Excellent trail. Well marked and relatively intuitive for the most part. Lots of inclines and descents throughout the loop with varying terrain. Beautiful views. Took about 2-2.5 hours for the pot lake loop at a brisk pace.', 'A great hike for an autumn day. The leaves are turning and the scenery is beautiful.  
The tree roots and rocks in the trail can be a bit of a challenge. It can be hard on the knees. 
The scenery is worth the hike!', 'beautiful trail! Nice way to spend 2-3 hrs. we took a snack and had a picnic at one of the many nice openings where we could see the lake. ', 'kids 7 and 5 were able to do it. lots of climbing around rocks which the kids loved, but can be hard on the knees. trail was fairly obvious, well beaten path and enough other hikers around to feel sure of where you are. ', 'lots of roots and rocks on the trail. It was dry when I hiked but you can see a few spots where it is usually muddy.', 'Great day for a hike. At the fork take the right it is more difficult but makes the return easier. Due to the weather this summer the trail is quite dry.', 'Nicely maintained moderate use. Very rocky and roots tail surface. Well marked. No bugs when we hiked 11 to 2 pm aug 14', 'This was a beautiful hike but was by far one of the more challenging ones I have completed, I would rate it closer to hard than moderate. The trail is moderate in that it is fairly easy to navigate and the slightly uneven ground to walk over branches and rocks most of the hike, however the length pushed it out of a moderate rating and into a hard for me, and there were points that could have used better marking too so you do have to be fairly comfortable with navigation. Despite it being a loop we somehow came out of the same place we went in which I assume is due to lacking markers towards the end of the trail, I ending up leading my self through the woods to the point I entered at rather than closing the loop.
', 'Loved this hike. Excellent variety in terrain with a nice challenge in elevation. ', "Great trail for running. Great elevation change and a variety of scenery. Bugs can be pretty dense so bring some bug spray!  Trail is easy to follow so don't worry about using your phone or GPS to guide you. Trail is marked and signs are at interesections detailing which way to go. Love this one.", 'great trail with some mildly challenging rocks and hills. ', 'I’ve done this three times in the last six weeks. It’s a great trail. Lots of big rocks and tree roots. For a well used trail I hardly encounter anyone on it. Was there after supper tonight and saw two people. ', 'Great hike. Lots of climbing and easy to navigate trails. Some markers along the way but the foot paths are pretty easy to spot to keep you on track. Definitely bring bug spray!', 'Very nice walk!!', 'Great spot for all levels of hikers!', 'Nice hike. Some steep sections to provide a workout. Lots of exposed tree roots as this is the first and most used loop. Not crazy busy this time of year.', 'beautiful day on the trail today. did it in 1h40 and was walking with a fast pace. most scenic views are to the right on the first half of the trail. will definitely be back', "was a beautiful day for a hike. parking lot to parking lot took me one hour forty minutes. I walk fairly quick and don't stop often for pictures unless something catches my eye. most of the scenic part of the trail is on the right side when you get to the fork. will definitely be back again !
", 'Nice 2 hour and 15 minute hike but quite frequent encounters on this loop.', "ran the pot lake loop. very beautiful and the trails are extremely well marked. also very close to the city if you're looking to get away quickly 
", 'This was only my second hike ever, parts were challenging, but overall great trail and view at the top. Can’t wait to try the rest of the loops!', 'Best done in May before bugs and people come out! Or in the Fall maybe.', 'Beautiful trail and views. We picked a very hot and humid day to hike here and will choose a cooler day next time. Luckily, we had lots of water with us and we took our time! Highly recommend this trail.', 'Really enjoyed this trail. Lots of great views. Well marked and easy to follow. Kids loved that there were lots of boulders to climb. Will be coming back to hike some of the other Bluff Trail loops.', 'I run this trail 1-2 times a year. A great workout and pushes me to my limits. If you are trail-running, plan at least an hour+ for this run and bring lots of water. If you are hiking, plan at least 3+ hours. everywhere along the course you will find great views.', 'Great hike. Really will do it again some day. I encourage everyone around to go and do it.', 'Great hike very beautiful with lots of places to stop and enjoy the view. As often said lots of roots and some climbs but all in all doable.', 'Great little trail.  Given my experience I would rate it as moderate. A lot of rocks and roots to walk through and a few good climbs.', 'Beautiful! Great moderate hike.', 'Hard', 'Great terrain. Good sized loop for an afternoon hike.', 'Great trail, great work-out!  Well marked and very clean.', 'Good trail and not super well marked which is fun, kind of close to the highway so you can hear the cars pretty much into the loop. only downside though', 'Beautiful trail! Definitely more challenging than expected. My only complaint is lack of trail marking can make it easy to get lost and end up on one of the longer loops!', 'this was a surprise for me and my girlfriend who enjoy challenging trails. I recommend this hike', 'Absolutely beautiful hiking trails, dog friendly on leash. Absolutely breathe taking views. Multiple trails within the one trail. Difficult at times but worth every minute.', 'Of all the 4 loops of the Bluff Wilderness, the Pot Lake Loop provides the best cardio workout.  Good signage to help you navigate from each trail loop and amazing views.', 'Great trail, lots of fun technical hills, with great views']

['Awesome views! Muddy but no bugs and worth every step!', 'Did the whole thing in one day… listening to music and using the app to track drained my battery way too quick, hence the gap in the trail map. Official time in 08:08 and time out 20:17… was shooting for 10 hours but still feel great about finishing it in one day.  Trail was pretty visible.  Got lost 1-2 times but I had the app to put me back on track… very wet and mucky in lots of spots.  Can’t wait to try it again next year for a better time.', 'The trail is breathtaking, in more ways then one.', "Completed the full loop counterclockwise with my mom and my dog. Note that the full loop is 51km and not 44.9km.

Day 1 (Red rocks - Seal Cove, 20km)
This is the longest day in kms, however the terrain is relatively flat for the most part. Not a very scenic day as most is spent in the woods. Camping at Seal Cove was great, we spent the night on the beach watching the sunset and my dog swimming. We had campsite #4 and it was good, the picnic table was nice to have.

Day 2 (Seal Cove - Refugee Cove, 18km) 
This is the most scenic day with lots of viewpoints. Very muddy though which definitely slows you down. The campsites at Refugee are really nice. We had #3 which also had a picnic table. It's a little walk getting to the beach though, which we were too tired to go so just stayed at the campsite.

Day 3 (Refugee Cove - Red Rocks, 13km)
Not as many kms but definitely more challenging with a big ascent right after leaving the campsite and then another big one going up an ATV trail. We also took the wooded trail at the end since we weren't sure about the tides, which gives you an extra 2km compared to taking the beach.

Mosquitos were REALLY bad when we went (Aug 22 - 24). Lots of water to filter and the trail is well marked. Overall great trail and could definitely see myself making it a yearly hike! :)", 'Awesome hike, 9/10 difficulty, beautiful views the whole way along the coast. Lots of water to drink the entire time too', 'Tough but stunning hike! We only did a portion of the park and climbed almost 2,000m in elevation. Loved it! So much so I am planning to do the 3 night/4 day total trail!! 
Finished with a 3k run along the shore in West Advocate!! ', "Stumbled on the trail ramdomly coming off of the beach. Cool views of the orange sand beach but over all hard trail. We didn't start at km 1 and had a hard time finding our way. There were no indications anywhere except for km's. So we had no idea how many km's all together. It was also quite a long hike before having an option to get out of the forest. Overall hard but I think would have appreciated it more if we knew what was coming and were more prepared. ", 'An awesome hike forsure! We hiked counter clockwise, the trail was quite muddy between little bald rock and eatonville but the views make up for that! The two huge hills everyone talks about are wheeler trails so going up isn’t to bad, it’s just a long haul to the top. Tons of water to fill up which is great and the campsites are pretty good! Some have actual picnic tables others just have boards and stumps to make a makeshift table. Also no fires are supposed to be allowed on the backcountry campsites, so that was a bummer, but still an amazing hike, would recommend!', "Very well-marked trail, with some beautiful views, lots of wildlife, and terrain variation. As some other reviewers have mentioned, there were some very boggy spots partway through, but nothing that couldn't be handled. 

Regarding wildlife, we saw eagles, rabbits, deer, and frogs, and a number of jays. 

We hiked the trail in 4 days, 3 nights. There is lots of beach access along many parts of the trail. 

Highly recommended for those interested in a multi-day hike. Remember that the tides in the area are dramatic and move quickly- keep an eye on your stuff if you have it on the beaches, and keep it above the tide line! ", 'Tough trail for sure, but an amazing experience. Did the loop counter clockwise in 4 days, three nights — it was nice to get the wooded area done on the first day, and then have the coast for the rest of the time. Plus counting down the kms was so motivating for me!
Some big hills up and down, and lots of muddy portions of the trail between Seal Cove and Refugee Cove. Saw lots of wildlife, and lots of friendly hikers and dogs.
Can’t wait to do it again!', 'Did the trail in 2 days, 1 night. Hiked from Red Rocks to Keyhole Brook (26.8km) then to Eatonville to complete 36.5km (in lieu of returning along the 15km inland part). If we had booked earlier we would have stayed in Big Bald Rock instead only because it’s a shorter distance, but no sites were available. Would recommend completing the trail clockwise since the hardest section is to Refugee Cove followed by the climb to get out of the cove. Occasionally felt blisters forming but with a little moleskin was able to stop them in their tracks. It would be a smart idea to bring hiking poles - about 50% of the people we saw didn’t have poles and I was genuinely concerned for their safety. The trail is very steep and muddy in sections and the poles were everything in those moments. Plenty of streams with clear water so finding water was never an issue. Wore hikers on day 1 and trail runners on day 2 and it felt great to have dry shoes. Will definitely do this trail again, perhaps over three days or book earlier so we can travel less on day 1. Do your research before going!! ', 'This is a hidden gem. The hiking was tough but the views were the pay off. There wasn’t a section of the whole loop that I would have wanted to miss. Three of us did this trail in three nights and four days. Glad I trained a little! ', 'Amazing but brutal trail. Hiked red rocks to little bald rock on day 1. Then to Eatonville on day 2 and finally back to red rocks on day 3. Lots of blister and sore legs by the end. Would definitely do it again just gave me a year to recover.', 'Wet in spots and getting wide as folks avoid the mud. Need some volunteer trail crew to lay some logs and work on drainage.
Well signed trail with great views of the bay of fundy (or sometimes just fog). 
Geologically interesting, lots of wildlife. 
One of very few multi day hikes with campsites in all of NS.', 'Definitely came as advertised!! ', 'Completed the full coastal loop with my partner and 10 year old daughter this past week. Absolutely stunning views and by far the most challenging hike any of us have ever completed. We cried and we laughed, lots of great memories! ', 'Wonderful long weekend trip. I’ve done this trail both dry and wet, and in both directions. The trail is a bit rough in the rain but manageable. I would highly recommend!', "Did this 51km loop clockwise in two nights, three full days of hiking with a friend and our two dogs. We started at the visitor center and stayed at Refugee Cove on night 1 and Seal Cove for night 2. Highly recommend both sites as the camp sites are right next to beautiful beaches. Not all sites have beach access so these two are a must! Difficult pace for only two nights especially if you want some down time but very enjoyable of you're up to the task :)", 'I ended up driving from New Brunswick Friday afternoon after work, and hiking into the dark. I had not planned my clothing well and was too cold to sleep in hammock so my dog and I ended up hiking the loop through the night. We were able to hear the ocean. But missed out on the views!! By daylight we were finishing up, signed out when lodge opened and slept in car for a few hours before driving home. Need to redo this. But it was a beautiful hike from the little bit we saw. It is longer then the site had said as well. We were happy to see the end when it finally came. ', 'Amazing trail! But it is 51.4 km and NOT 44.9 as All Trails claims. First day is 12 km to Refugee Cove is a tough and technical section with 3 big climbs and descents - including one extremely steep descent - and ending in Refugee Cove. We spent our second night 14 km later at Keystone Brook which was a great site. We would have preferred to get to Seal Cove but because of a late start and ran out of daylight at 5pm and wanted to be able to see the stunning coastline. Day 3 was therefore 25 km back to the parking lot. It was a great stroll through the woods with a big ascent and decent towards the end. The trail was well marked. I wish they had names for all of the lookouts. Absolutely stunning coastline. ', 'Trail Run - 50km Full Loop: 

Started the route on the overland section to Eatonville. The trail was in good condition for running and I covered the first 18km in about 2.5 hours. The west coast section was quite a bit slower due to a combination of steep declines and inclines, lots of tricky tree roots, and skirting frequent wet sections but also beach visits, photo ops, snack breaks, view points, etc. It is absolutely beautiful on the west coast section. I was about 4.5 hours on this section. As soon as I turned the corner at the cape the trail running conditions improved and I was able to maintain a decent pace except for the steep climbs out of Refugee Cove and Mill Creek. 

Total time for the full loop 9hrs 10min. 

Water: there were lots of places to get water along the route. I drank directly from streams the whole way. ', 'Really great time! I did this around the middle of July and there wasn’t one mosquito or black fly! 

Red rocks-Refugee Cove
Refugee Cove-Seal Cove
Seal Cove-Eatonville

Refugee was my favourite place. Tide was out so I explored to the right of the beach and took in all of the wonderful cliffs and rocks. Stayed at site one at both camp sites and those were both good spots. Lots of places for water which is lovely. I’d consider doing this in 3 nights, 4 days next time to thoroughly enjoy it. ', 'Longest day for me, the part missing on my recording...forgot on pause!!   People say its the boring part of the loop, mostly in the wood.  But i really enjoy it, peaceful in the wood :)', "This is a great trail with amazing views!!  I definitely recommend this trail, and will do it again next year.  As the distances aren't too long between campsites and the hills aren't too bad, this trail is suited to new and seasoned backpackers.  There are plenty of water sources along the entire trail.

Day 1: Visitor center to Refugee Cove - 3h45m.  Took a short break at mill brook.  This section of the trail was well maintained with a few hills.  There are a handful of points that allow you to see the coast.  Stayed in RC1.  Sites 1 and 2 looked nice.  I didn't see the other sites.  Just past site 2 on the right there is a little opening with a great tree for a PCT bear hang. A short walk from campsite to beach with cook kit, made for a nice supper.

Day 2: Refugee Cove to Eatonville - 8h15m. the morning was foggy with no views, but it cleared up by lunch. This section was definitely the most scenic.  There are so many great spots for photos and take in the views.  Terrain was very rooty, but not much for hills.  A few short ups and downs.  Around km marker 25, got stung in the back of the head.  Didn't see or hear any nest until it was too late.  Lunch at Big Bald, and a couple breaks.  Arrived at Seal cove(original booking) at 3:30pm and wanted to push on.  Called and change my res to Eatonville.  Arrived at Eatonville at 5pm.  I had site 1 which is a great site.  Site 2 right beside is great also.  Both are right next to a good section of the brook.  Had difficulty finding a good tree for bear hang, but as I was the only one in the entire Eatonville campground, there was a great tree in site 2 to use.

Day 3: Eatonville to visitor center - 3h15m. It was very misty and wet, so I was motivated to get off the trail before the rain (supposed to hit afternoon).  The first and last parts of this section have a couple hills, but the middle is very flat (along brooks), so you can make some good time.  Although this section has no coastal views, it is quite pretty in spots.  If this was a dry day, I imagine I would have found myself stopping to look at the scenery.", 'The squirrels here really don’t mess about!! Hang all of your food properly as soon as you get to camp, they won’t hesitate to chew through anything your food is in. 

Other than that this trail is absolutely amazing!! We did 3 nights in total, doing it in reverse. 
Parking - Seal Cove - 6.5 hrs
Seal Cove - Big Bald Rock - 4.5hrs
Big Bald Rock - Refugee Cove - 4.5 hrs
Refugee Cove - Parking - 3 hr 15

We were really happy to get the 20k out of the way. Took lots of long breaks for views and really enjoyed the hikes on days 2 and 3. We were all warmed up to get the last day done quite quickly. All the campsites were really nice and the views here are just spectacular!! 

Would love to do this again, 4 days was perfect! Bringing poles next time though!

', 'Fantastic hike! The trail is well-marked and maintained, as are the facilities. They clean the "pit privies" every 2 days. This was my first solo multi-day hike, and it was a really great one for it. I will definitely do this one again!

I hiked in a counter-clockwise direction staying at Seal Cove, Big Bald Rock, and finally Refugee Cove. I wanted to get the long 20 km day through mostly forests over with first, although that left the most difficult day for the end. One thing I really liked about doing it this way was that you hike through forests all day, and then finally getting to the coast and seeing those amazing views just makes it that much more breath-taking.

BEWARE OF SQUIRRELS. When I got to Big Bald Rock campsite, I dropped my pack and went to check out the beach. I made sure everything was closed up so rodents/squirrels/etc didn't get in. When I got back, a squirrel had chewed a hole in my pack. That night, the squirrels chewed a hole in my sealine bag which I had HUNG UP to deter wildlife from getting my food. I am very grateful to the other campers who saved my food from being totally ravaged by the squirrels. Hang your food, hang it well, and don't leave any food or food bags unattended even for a moment.', 'well maintained trail. did it in 3 days 2 nights. the campsite at little bald rock was nice and worth the extra kms. we got our campsite stolen at eatonville wich was a little annoying but luckily 2 other hiker shared a campsite and gave us one. overall excellent trail, lots of ups and down and lots of viewpoints. i highly recommend amd will do it again this year.', 'Another year, another fun trip! That last part from Seal Cove to Eatonville is so tough… I always miss and get high Tide. I debate going counter clockwise next year, but then I’ll miss the grand finale of the three sisters view… Though it would be cool doing the Eatonville day trails and getting more glimpses… The only camp I wouldn’t recommend is probably keyhole Brook… Every other site has its own special piece of the puzzle… I love doing this in super hot conditions. I was so grateful it didn’t rain… I did it in four days and three nights so I could really take it in… But in the future I might add another night on… Because I was in paradise being there.  ', 'It’s definitely no walk in the park...haha. What an amazing trail. I’ll post more shortly', 'Great hike from Eatonville Rd near km#36 into Sealy Cove -km#30.5... nice ocean breeze... just shy 12km in/out.', "My partner and I did the full loop in 2nights/3days and it was very challenging for us, but a beautiful hike! Highly recommend, just make sure you are prepared. Lots of great water sources and lookoff points. 

Red Rocks to Refugee Cove - Day 1
- about 13km when you factor in getting right to the site, took us 5 hours with a few breaks
- The tide was in when we arrived, so we couldn't shortcut through the beach
- intense inclines and declines, but this segment is pretty well maintained
- I don't recommend site RC7, it's covered in tree roots
Refugee Cove to Seal Cove - Day 2
- everyone said this day would be easier, I'm not too sure about that. Inclines and declines were less severe, but constant and you really feel the extra kms! 
- Most scenic day, trail is right against the coastal cliff most of the day
- be warned that off-beach sites at SC are up a hill from the beach, water source and privy
Seal Cove to Red Rocks - Day 3
- Seal Cove to Eatonville is similar terrain to the day before, we finished in ~1:45
- after Eatonville things flatten out quite a bit and you're hiking through a forest along a river. 
- tide was out and the beach shortcut was a lifesaver!", 'The trail ended at my last attached photo, I drove off a bit before stopping the app. Probably 1K thereabouts.', 'Excellent Trip. Elevation Tracker on this app is deceiving. Use a Topo Map instead.', 'Absolutely loved the trail... we have done it in 2 days stayed the night at Keyhole and split the hike pretty much 50/50... the first day was about 9 hours and the second day was 8ish... it was great challenge... definitely something i would do again! Only thing i would change would be staying the night at Seal Cove so we could have evening/morning swim but that would push first day to almost 30k... ', 'What a beautiful trail in Nova Scotia! Did the trail over 3 days and wished I had done it over 4. Also enjoyed the wooded part of the trail through Eatonville it was shaded and relatively easy terrain. ', '4d/3n 36km - 1 Adult + 2 Kids (11Y,9Y)

First multi-day backpacking trip w the kids. 

They carried water, sleeping bag, sleeping pad, clothes, daily trail snacks and personal survival/first aid kit...kept their packs lite.

Itinerary w hiking times (includes breaks)

Day 1 - Shuttle to Eatonville, Eatonville to Seal Cove. 2.5 hrs

Day 2 - Seal Cove to Big Bald. 4 hrs

Day 3 - Big Bald to Refugee. 4 hrs

Day 4 - Refugee to Red Rocks. 4.5 hrs

We got lucky w the weather and had a great time. ', 'Once again this hike did not disappoint. Other than a lot of blow downs from this past year it was still a treat to get away in this amazing scenery for 3 days. The weather was amazing, not many bugs that I noticed and the evenings were just perfect with the breeze coming off the bay. Met some great fellow hikers who shared there stories and experiences. Thanks Wade, Gwen and Holly...it always make the trail better meeting quality hikers/people like this. All in all it was another great and somewhat challenging hike. ', 'Civiized trails though includes the two toughest climbs of fou  TV day trip. Occasional shore view, but a long day to finish
', 'Big Bald Rock to Refugee cove, trail not so rough as earlier sections. Refugee cove is special
Great views', 'Eatonville campsites to Big Bald Rock
Difficult with blowdowns and mud on a mainly rough trail. Lots of climbs. Nice coastal views including 3 sisters', 'Redrocks to Eatonville campsites
Primitive rough trail, many blowdowns and mud bogs. Bugs were worst ever. Very difficult day and boring being entirely in woods.', 'Recommend beautiful, rugged black diamond trail run with plenty of wildlife (saw 3 deer and their constant tracks, birds,  beaver, and bear scat, etc). I ran it counter-clockwise. Very difficult this way leaving dozens of huge elevation gains till last. Loads of mud, washed out sections and fallen trees. I was able to run two-thirds of the trail today: power hiked, scrambled and climbed the rest.', 'Amazing trail! Completed it at the end of last summer. Challenging at some points but every view point is very worth it. If you start from the visitor centre and hope to make it a loop, the final stretch back to the parking lot is essentially just walking on a road....Would recommend contacting the park regarding a pick up option if you’d prefer to skip this. Also found the backcountry hiking camp sites fairly buggy and dark, opt’d to sleep on the beaches at the kayaking campsites and it was heaps more enjoyable!', "One of the most beautiful hikes I've completed to date! Rather challenging if you plan for longer days, but rewarding nonetheless. 3 days 2 nights is certainly enough to complete the trail. We hiked clockwise and I would definitely do that direction again. Ran into 3 groups of people the entire time we were on the trail so it was nice and quiet. A significant amount of muddy patches to go around between Refugee and Seal Cove, but that could have also been because of the hurricane. One of the best marked trails I have ever experienced as well. ", "Beautiful trail. Can't wait to do it again. Reserving cabins and carrying less gear was a great option I'm glad we took. ", 'Absolutely incredible views across rugged terrain. My husband and I just completed this hike in 3 days, 2 nights. We took a shuttle from Advocate to Eatonville, opting out of the 14k wooded portion of this trail. We started in Eatonville day one and hiked to Big Bald Cabin (which was such perfect end to the day). Approximately 15k, a couple of real good inclines and declines and lots of muck (we went 2 days after a large rain storm). Day 2 was Bug Bald to Refugee Cove (9k). This was the hardest day for us, as we pushed ourselves a bit harder than we should have on day one. We had a late start and had to push to make it before dark. This portion of the trail was very mucky, so wear waterproof hiking boots and take poles. You’ll thank yourself. There were some sketchy “bridges” as well. Watch your footing. Day three was Refugee back to Red Rocks (13k). Mill brook was both an incredible climb down and up, but the views are stunning. We timed ourselves so we could finish the hike with the shortcut on the beach. Despite the wicked hills, day three was our favourite. The trail had no mud and was easy to navigate. All in all, it took us about 15-16 hours hike time. Happy Hiking! ', "Very nice loop with some decent ascends and descends. I did the loop in 3 days (with overnights at Little Bald Rock and Eatonville).

The trail itself is very well marked and easy to follow. The paths are clear and very well maintained. Along the coastal trail there's some roots sticking out which makes it a bit more technical, but still easy going. You just have to watch your steps a little bit.

Little Bald Rock is a nice small campground. Easy access to a water source and you can watch the sunset on the cliffs. For me, Eatonville was full of mosquitos so not very enjoyable. The campsite itself however was nice with a table and a nice stream to cool down in. Note for both campsites, the surface is hard, so pegs might not be ideal.

For someone who's fit and used to hiking (read: exercises several times a week, including running), this shouldn't be too much of a struggle. 3 days was plenty of time for me (hence me adding McGahey Brook Canyon Loop to it at the end) and I'll be doing it again in 2 days with an overnight at Keyhole Brooks. When you're not used to hiking/running, the climbs will set you back, so be prepared. Take it slow and take breaks when necessary.

Highly recommend this. Good starter to get into multi day backpacking.

I've seen comments with regards to dissapointing views. It is true, you're hiking in the forest for a substantial amount of time, so be aware of this. However, you do descend to several beaches, the most significant ones being Peggy's Cove and Seal's Cove, which give you stunning views as well as several lookouts along the way. To me, the best views are in between Little Bald Rock and Eatonville.", '9 of us, with varying experience and fitness, hiked the trail in 4 days with nights at Refugee Cove, Big Bald Rock (in a cabin) and Seal Cove (which was the highlight).  Mosquitoes were minimal, trail well marked but expect difficult footing at some points. While it was hard it was manageable by all. We’ve hiked in British Columbia and Alberta so enjoyed a chance to hike in eastern Canada. Highly recommend stopping at Wild Caraway for post hike refueling in Advocate for amazing food. ', "2 of us did this in 3 days, 2 nights and took us about 15h of hiking to complete including rest stops.  We're in fairly good shape.  Night 1 was at Eatonville camp site.  Time from leaving to camp was 5hours, and included a 6km mistake we made by taking the wrong path at first, totally our fault. This could have easily been only a 4hour section and was easiest part of the whole trip.  Once you get out of that first climb before the tail split it's cake.  Night 2 we went to Refuge Cove, and this was 24km.  It was a long day, and we pushed really hard.  Took us 8.5 including breaks and lunch.  Then on the 3rd day Refuge Cove to Visitor Center was 3 hours.  We were pretty motivated because it was raining.  Bugs weren't bad at all, only got bit a one evening.  If i was to do it again, I'd go Visitor Center -> Seal Cove, Seal Cove to Refuge Cove, Refuge Cove -> Visitor Center.  Lengthen the first day, have a shorter second.

Highly recommended.", 'This review is in response to Dan's AT "cool-down" comment: in no way should this trail been considered relaxed. In addition to the 2000m of climbing and descending, the 47.4 kms of this trail are technically challenging and as hard as anything you'll find around. There are few easy miles, with the trail usually at grade or littered with rocks and roots. I'm sure an AT veteran would enjoy the challenge of this loop, but an honest and humble hiker or runner would not call the terrain "quite relaxed."

I've hiked and run in many place in North America, and that's my take.', 'Had an amazing time doing the loop with my dad. Took us 2 1/2 days to do it. The first day we did 12km next we did 23km last we did 14km. Beautiful views and easy to follow trail.', 'trail was in great condition
had a wonderful time stayed the first night at refugee cove and the second at seal cove. not too hard of a trail but still pretty rugged terrain as you have to climb and descend lots of hills on the first day.
beautiful views and well worth it ', 'We just did the red rock loop.  It was nice walking on the beach at low tide.  The walk back up the stairs and on the ridge line was a little more uphill than we would have liked.', 'Hiked this loop as a "cool-down" hike after just completing the Appalachian Trail. Other than a couple steep sections, the terrain is quite relaxed and the views are spectacular! Other than the ~15km forest section between Red Rocks and Eatonville, you get some stunning views along the coastline the rest of the way... make sure you leave time to take the short side trails to viewpoints and beaches! Very abundant wildlife as well. ', 'The reviews are a bit misleading for this hike. We wanted to do a coastal hike and this one matched the description perfectly. We hiked the whole loop starting with the wooded side. We knew it would be challenging but the whole hike was literally straight up and down. There is no level area. There were only a few clearings to stop and see the ocean and they were gorgeous but I really thought there would be more considering 2/3 is coastal trail. The highlight of this hike was Seal Cove, a beautiful rock beach with great scenery. Also the only place on the hike to get a break from the mosquitoes. We stopped here for a break but I wish we had camped here. This hike is a good workout, there are tons of streams to re-supply water. It’s 99% wooded views though and I came back with 120 (yes, I counted) mosquito bites so wear a net or bring double the bug spray.', 'Nice day of woods hiking. Trail a little wet after two nights of rain. Decent climb in the middle and high decent at the end.', 'Challenging terrain today. Lots of roots and mud along the trail. Still a nice hike with some beautiful lookoffs along the way. Beach at seal cove is an excellent place to stop for a rest.', 'This is a great trail for beginners for multi-day hiking. ', 'Great trail.  Mix of extremely challenging climbs, technical trail, and a handful of stretches where you can run or pick up the pace.', 'Super-nice and challenging trail! I did hike/trailrun it last Tue/Wed and was almost alone. I spent the night in Seal Cove; since it started raining, I decided to do the main part if the trail on the 2nd day. 
Because of the rain, the trail was quite muddy at sections, but doable.
Some of the look offs are superfluous but many reward with great views. ', "Pretty awesome east coast hike. A group of us did it in 2 night and 3 days. We stayed at refugee cove the first night, and Carey Brook Cabin the second night. The cabins are very nice compared to a campsite, but comes at a cost (Id recommend them if you are struggling to do distance, or if its cold). There are plenty of rivers to get fresh water from so just bring a water filter. The last part of the trail on the north side past eatonville road is rather dull as it is a walk in a forest with moderate elevation gain. In our group of 4, on the last day I left from Carey Brook Cabin and hiked back to the car at the HQ (20.7KM), while the other 3 waited for me on Eatonville road for a ride. Eatonville road is a gravel road, would recommend a SUV, Jeep, or a truck to drive back there our 2010 corolla did fine though.

Most of the trail is inside the forest, but some times popes out to rock beaches, and once to an open field area. There are some cliff jumping spots near the middle of the trail (10', 40' and probably ~60') jumps, but you have to time the tide just right so you dont get sucked out into the bay. During late August the mosquitos were fairly bad. There were plenty of people on the trail, and there is no sense of danger. Just follow Leave No Trace procedures and you should be fine.", 'Super pretty and fun hike! Did it in 2 days, 3 nights (Seal Cove and Refugee Cove). Hike to refugee cove was beautiful and challenging. Between the two camp sites was a lot more flat than day 1, a long but steady hike. Seal cove to the trailhead is a bit boring, you follow along an old road. Found out later if you ask, there is a shuttle you can pay for and skip the less scenic part of the hike.', 'Overall it was an amazing hike. We did the loop backwards. Extremely rewarding. Amazing views. Loads of looks offs. 

After reading reviews and talking to folks we expected the hike to be far more challenging. 
We would recommend this trail as a pre cursor to the Fundy foot path (friends we did the loop with us and said the footpath is far more challenging)', 'Amazing trail with great views. It is a challenging hike but well worth the time and effort. Will be back to hike this again in the near future.', 'Amazing trail!! We had great weather with no rain but high humidity. Stayed at Refugees Cove and Seal Cove both had swimming beaches which was great as it was mid-July when we were on the trail. Highly recommend!', 'Beautiful trail beautiful scenery! Rated as hard and it is but well worth it. Did the trail in 3 days but would probably opt in doing it in 4 next time to enjoy it more. Refugee cove and Seal cove campsites were perfect! Would recommend for sure!', 'Just hiked this for the first time with some friends who do it annually, we did the loop in 1 day ... which was not easy ... and didn’t really give the opportunity to see the beauty at each lookout ... would recommend taking two days', 'Absolutely the most beautiful place in Nova Scotia ❤️❤️', 'Simply Beautiful.', 'great views.  plenty of long climbs but space between them to gather your steam back.
Can be done in 3 days, 4 at a more moderate pace.', "This trail was challenging and exhilarating all at the same time. The first day we hiked 12 ish from visitors center to Refugee. There were 3 climbs and descents that were said to be 45 degrees steep and one km in length each way. It was a long, slow zigzag descent and an even slower ascent on the other side. With each down we knew there was an up coming. Honestly, I'd rather go up than down. 
Day 2 -we hiked 8ish km from Refugee to Big Bald Brooke. It was a spectacular day and absolutely beautiful scenery. There were some ups and downs, but not like day 1. The camp sites at big bald were lovely and we cooled off and cleaned up in the brooke right beside our camp site. 
Day 3- we planned on hiking to Seal Cove (7 km) but things changed and we decided to boogy out to Eatonville where were parked a car. Day 3 was rainy and foggy in the morning. However, even with the fog it was obvious that the views would be sellar on a clear day.
TIPs: not for the faint of mind or heart.
TIP 2: take electrolyte drink or tabs to replenish what was lost  in sweat
TIP 3: purify all water!!!
TIP 4: Be sure to hang food in a tree. 10' high, 5' out from the tree to avoid bears thinking you are the restaurant.
 
Above all... SMILE and enjoy", "One of the best backpacking trips we've done!", 'Two and a half days of travel. This was a great excursion for my buddies and I. Challenging but amazing look offs.

"Task......Reward" 

-Justin', "Beautiful Trail! The looped trail offers amazing backcountry camping without having to retrace your steps. New and amazing views every day. Did the full loop hike in 3 days and 2 nights. But for a relaxing pace and to have more 'down time' at your camping spots, I suggest 4 days and 3 nights. The best spots to stop for the night are Refugee Cove and Seal Cove. I have hiked the full trail in both July and August, both times water supplies were plentiful.", 'Hiked this trail back in 2013 as soon as it was open with my husband. It was quite challenging with gear and took us 5 nights and 6 days. 
We enjoyed the trip a lot. Plenty of chances to see the ocean and take pictures.', 'hiked for 3 beautiful days at the end of September. Perfect time of year for this trail. keep your energy levels up:-)', 'Just finished a five night, six day backpacking trip on this trail. It can be done in as little as three days. I took my time to see this beautiful coastal trail and met some amazing hikers along the trip. This is by far one of the best backpacking trails in Atlantic Canada. The trail is well marked and has plenty of streams and brooks so you never have to worry about drinking water. Water treatment is required ie: Tablets, water filtration pump. The tent sites are very well placed from the main trail and all have access to running streams to outdoor toilets. The trail can be challenging at times, but never extreme. The trails goes from Beautiful moss covered forests floors to amazing coastal views. This is a must see for anyone looking for minimally untouched wilderness.  Simply amazing!', "We had a great time just my husband and I.  We did the trail in 3 days, two nights.  It was quite the workout. Lots of ups and downs. The first day we hiked 20.8 Km.  It was the hardest day.  Climbing with a full heavy backpack and water. We stayed at little bald rock.  Couldn't make it to big bald rock, it was getting late and wanted to setup camp before dark.  The second day we hiked 16.09 Km .  It was challenging at times, but we were able to have a few longer stops which one included a swim in the cold bay.  It was great! We stayed at Seal Cove. Beautiful beach site where guided kayak tours stays overnight. Our third day hike was 22.2 Km. 
The hardest day was day one. We say lots of wildlife and slept under the sounds of waves and squirrels chirping.  
Our GPS and cell phone died throughout the trail, and off/on cloudy days prevented our solar charger to help us keep a full tracking of our journey. 
We plan to do it again soon, but in 4 days,3 nights, so we can enjoy our evenings.  This trip was done more as a workout trip, and by 8pm we were dead tired in bed for the night.", 'Beautiful !', 'Great hike, nice trails, might be rough for beginners, lots of up and down hills some quite steep, views are breathtaking. Went there unprepared, if i go again will def bring tent and sleep 1-2 nights to see as much as possible. ']

['Great walk on the beach to get to the actual trail and the views on the trail are amazing. ', 'I hated walking over the beach rocks  but this trail was worth it! ', 'lovely trail!!! amazing views. easy going. ', 'Not a walk in the park!

opening and closing on the beach, with your choice of sand or lose rock. The trail proper has excellent views over minor elevation change. several easy over/easy under tree falls.  Corduroy logs in serious need of some TLC, but nothing impassable with some willingness to get muddy.', 'A little rocky in parts but lovely seashore!', 'Tons of fun! have done this trail twice, last year and this! Caught the sunset at Gaff Point through the fog and was still beautiful. Next trip we will hunt for thw hidden beach  ', "Beautiful, and well maintained!!! There's one part during the loop that gets you pretty close to a cliff, so beware if you have a fear of heights. It made my stomach turn! But otherwise loved it, and got to see some wildlife too", 'beautiful trail! ', 'Took the trail less travelled along the right side of the cliff and it was lovely! Lead us to a secret beach??!! Incredible views of the fog lifting as we came back along the left', 'great trail. well maintained, with beautiful views
', 'Very nice. Clean. Cool logs to walk on in places. Beautiful views. When we got to the Loop we went around anti-clockwise and would recommend.￼', 'Beautiful trail, great views! Busy on a beautiful summer day.', 'Excellent', 'Beautiful trail, easy terrain.', 'Wonderful', 'Beautiful! Takes about an hour and 40 minutes at a good pace.
', 'The beach part took a while because the trail is over a lot of rocks. But once you get past the beach the rest of the trail is good!', 'Beautiful trail. Very well maintained and the views are well worthy of the 5 km hike', 'Beauty!  Of the 4.1 miles, 3.9 was breathtaking.', ' Beautiful beach and trial! Highly recommend. ', 'One of my favorite trails in NS! The scenery was amazing.', 'Cool walk in but a warmer walk out. Trail is getting more rugged each year.', 'Beautiful hike, easy trail, family friendly. Lucked out with low tide and did not have to deal with beach cobble. Fantastic ocean views the entire trail.', 'ROCKS ROCKS ROCKS oh u want to on a trail, prepare for an unsteady walk on q rocky Beach (1,5km) before u even get to the trail. pack an extra pair of ankles', 'Wonderful hike! Not hard and stunning. very well cared for.
', 'Awesome hike. Beautiful views everywhere you look. ', 'Incomparable ocean scenery, but the beach there is rocky, and the logs on the trail offer a solid but bumpy path. Wear good shoes, and try to visit at low tide.', 'Great trail, pretty easy walk other than the cobbles from the beach. Well marked! Bring some good waterproof sneakers as it’s quite mucky after rain.  ', 'Trail is in good shape and 98% ice free. Great views. Not a lot of traffic.', 'Went on this trail with three of my best friends. We drove down from Hali in my friends sexy white charger. There is levels to Gaff Point, it’s like multiple experiences on the same trail. It’s the perfect length and honestly a top 3 trail for me. ', ' this one was really hard on old girl hips. lots of roots and rock in the loop. walking along the beach section even in low tide was challenging.  sunny day and beautiful views, saw a really big bunny and two eagles. be careful close to the cliffs especially if you take a dog. ice was gone and mud was starting to thaw. thanks to the folks who maintain the trail with addition of logs and wooden bridges.

', 'Trail starts out on the beach so it’s a bit rocky, definitely need good ankle support! Views are beautiful', 'The snow on the trail through the Nature Conservancy land is packed down nicely with only a couple patches of ice on the way up the hill. Lovely spot, with a seal hanging out in the beach on the way back to the parking lot.', 'Trail was nice and packed down which made it easy to follow', 'Great well marked trail but one spot at the halfway point had me searching for the yellow markers. Definitely want a good pair of hiking boots with ankle support as you are walking on beach rocks, shale and logs in various places. Lovely look off points in places. Definitely muddy and wet along many spots. The trail says 6.5km but my Fitbit tracker said 7.5km from the parking lot. On the return, took the trail on the hill next to the beach but owners ask you only do so when no horses in the field. Some people had their dogs but do caution that the shale along the ocean may be rough on their paws. Enjoy!', 'Easy hike, trail is a little slick. I’ve done it before In the summer and the trail can be muddy.', 'Beautiful trail, proper hiking footwear is needed. high cliffs and beautiful ocean views; I recommend this trail pack a lunch and bring your camera.', 'Definitely not an "easy" trail. Need good, solid hiking boots as you walk along pebbles at first and then later slippery rock. Well marked. Beautiful views!', 'Beautiful hike! I’ve done this one a few times, never gets old.', 'Well kept trail with stunning scenery. As others have pointed out, there is a variety of terrain so wear proper footwear. Overall an easy hike and well worth doing. ', 'Easy trekking, well marked with yellow paint markers & beautiful views. Loved the varied types of pathways along the trail: stone, split logs, corduroy logs..nice mix up. It was chilly starting out but was a great day to be hiking today!', 'Great trail, beautiful scenery.', 'Excellent! Well marked and gorgeous views. Third time back and still love it!', "If you haven't done this trail, well, you should... great trail with awesome views and moderate difficulty... Sunset is stunning if you can time your hike well.", 'The trail itself was only challenging at the beginning- as in walking over the beach rocks. I used the private property hill on the way back because I found it so atrocious. 
The trail is for the most part clearly marked with yellow indicators so you don’t get lost. Whether it be on trees or rocks by the sea side just follow them. 
The path is well maintained and an easy adventure walk. The scenery is absolutely stunning. The trail took me 7.5 KM and 2 hours as I dilly dallied a bit to take photos and footage on my camera. 
I didn’t have any problems with ticks. 
', 'Beautiful evening for the hike. 70 mins to complete.', 'The rocks at the beginning were not too easy to negotiate but the rest of the trail was great!', 'So, the first thing you need to know is that google maps sends you to the wrong place. No worries, the local residents have erected some signs to prevent you from going down the wrong road. Just keep going past the last road that google wants you to turn on and, instead, turn on Hirtle Beach Rd. There is a large parking lot there and it’s fairly obvious you’ve arrived.

The parking lot was packed but not full when we arrived in a Saturday at 11:00 AM. By the time we left at 1:30 PM, people were parking up and down the road

The only crappy part was walk the first/last part of walking across the rocks at the beginning/end along Hirtle beach. It’s a rock painters dream, however. Do yourself a favour and take the uphill walk along the cliff to save yourself some walking on the rocks. It’s private property but the owners only ask you to stay away if the horses are in the field. 

It took about 25 minutes to get to the trail proper. It eventually is a loop. There is an earlier point that looks like it might be the loop but watch for the yellow markers. They lead you to the left. At the actual split, you can go either left or right. Left is a bit more challenging. 

Trail is easy to moderate. The kids and dogs can do it but not strollers. The Hirtle Beach portion is not for weak ankles or flip flops. 

Took is an hour and 5 minutes to reach Gaff Point in the middle. Nice inukshuks there and a few spots to stop for snack/break. Some really nice coastal views along the way. Trail is very mixed between wide forest path and walking along slate rocks. It is well marked with yellow paint. Trail conditions are great. ', 'Great trail, pretty well marked and we found the secret beach. It starts on a beach and there’s all kinds of terrain but ultimately it’s a pretty easy, slightly moderate spot. Great views! ', 'Amazing trail! Moderate difficulty. Worth the view!', 'A must do. Great scenery of the ocean and interesting rock formations', 'Terrain changed from sand to beach rock, to roots and granite rock.  West stable shoes.  Beautiful view.  There is a hidden beach but it was busy so not that secret and that was a cooler week day', 'Very nice trail but very difficult to find due to incorrect directions on Google Maps. ', 'Beauty!!', 'beautiful trail with a great beach. bring your swimsuit for some water fun after this hike. the waves are bomb.', "A beautiful hike. Going at low tide is best so you can walk on the sandy beach. Otherwise you'll have to walk on the beach stones which is a bit awkward. There are some gorgeous views from the cliffs. ", 'Love this coastal trail! Make sure to repel down to the sandy beach below. Spectacular views of the ocean and islands.  ', '2 days in a row! Spectacular hike', 'Check my instagram for 12 min video. Awesome spot. Loved the walk and sights do not disappoint! Have proper footwear. No flipflops. @drscottmaclean #gaffpointtrail', 'Great trail. It was a foggy day but still a great trail. Well maintained and easy to follow. Crossing a Stoney beach to start and end trail was the roughest ground. It was busy we met about 6 groups along the trail.', 'Great and not to busy when I arrived at 10am. That changed when i returned to my car though.', 'Beautiful trail. You have to walk on the beach for about 20 mins to get there which was nice as well. Few spots have downed trees on the trail but nothing too onerous to cross. ', "rocky along the water but fine once you hit the trail. honestly I've done a lot of hiking and this has been the best hike to date! Comparable to Taylor Head but I would say I enjoyed this more..  we even got to dip in the very cold and refreshing ocean afterward. highly recommend checking this one out!!!", 'Loved this trail! A few trees down across the trail after storms this year. Not too hard to crawl around them though! ', 'My definition of the perfect hike.  The trail is well marked and offers fantastic views throughout.  Loved the different terrain at various parts of the trail - from well-worn dirt paths, smooth rounded rocks, wooden planks, flat top stones, and more.  The trail is well maintained.', 'Awesome trail. Hiked along the beach until we got to the trail head just to the right. Extremely well marked once you’re on the trail. We kept to the left along the loop where we hiked through an area of sharp-ish rocks with a gorgeous ocean view. The point is a great place to stop and have a quick bite to eat. The way back was a bit wet with a couple of tree stumps to climb over but very well maintained. There were zero bugs but it was also only 14 degrees when we did the hike. Can’t wait to go back!', 'I love this trail. The only downfall at all is that the first and last is a very rocky 1 km each way that can be hard on the ankles but the rest is great and probably one of the best hikes on the south shore.', 'Trail is pretty well kept. Absolutely gorgeous views but a lot of the time you’re watching what your stepping on (on a lot of rocks). Very busy, thin trails. Great for a family walk.', 'Has to be one of the best trials I’ve explored so far. The trail was easily hiked and the views at every turn were breathtaking. Definitely recommend this trial. Will be back again.', 'Great trail, beautiful sites', 'One of my favourite hikes this year. We went a few days after Hurricane Dorian, so there were several downed trees across parts of the trail. That made some parts tricky, but still passable. The views are spectacular and worth climbing over some trees! We did it with our two dogs, they did find walking on the beach through the pebbles a bit difficult. ', "Wonderful views dry trail end of August, wear supportive comfortable shoes for the beach rocks and navigating tree roots, did the whole route in under 2 hrs taking time to stop for several photos along the point, if you choose to do only half the loop start on the left side for views if you don't mind some spots beach rock, someone painted yellow markers here n there for trail, can appreciate the logs in the marshy area that is needed during rains but personally didn't favour them on this dry day, the cliffs and mosses were beautiful and I would walk it again.", 'Great hike, lot of nice views. The trail is well maintained, Recommend going out at low Tide.', 'Trail was a great quick hike. From start to finish took me 1 hour 20 minutes with no stops in between. This trail is not strenuous but you definitely have to be sure footed on the beach rocks.', 'Went on 03/08/2019. Started trail at noon, from Hirtle's Beach parking lot. The whole trail took us about 2 hours, with numerous stops and a swim at Hirtle's beach at the end. Walk down the beach for a couple kms to get to the actual trailhead. There's a few options to this: Walk on the sand, then up the rocks, or cut onto the farmer's private property and follow the foot trail up and back down the hill. We decided to walk along the beach. The rocks aren't that difficult, but witnessed some people struggling with their footing. An information board with a trail map indicates the started of the provincially maintained trail. You walk in abit and theres a three-pronged junction. Two of those have yellow spray paint indicating the trail to follow (That is used as the trail marker). This is the start of a loop. We took the right-most trail, hiking the trail clockwise. It is easy hiking through the forest, with numerous viewpoints of the ocean. The third path, the furthermost left trail, is an unmaintained foot path that'll lead you to the so-called "secret beach". This trail weaves along the cliff edge, and you may think that you're lost, but follow it to the end. Once arriving at the end, theres an overlook of the beach down below. Access it via the rope. Could be slippery if if was a wet day, so use your better judgement. Same can be said for swimming at that beach.  
I would say the hike is a 3.5/5. Not that challenging, but on a nice day its a good afternoon hike. Not strenuous in the slightest. ', 'I went at 8am on a Friday morning and there were 3 people at the beach and no one else on the trail. The volunteers do a great job of maintaining the trail though I felt a few yellow blazes could have been added. Gorgeous scenery though. Take tick spray and wear solid boots.', 'What an awesome hike. This trail is worth every minute of driving to get to. Don’t miss the unmarked trail to the hidden secret. ', 'Was a trail with beautiful views by the cliffs and on the beach.  Watch out for ticks and make sure you bring bug repellant. Trail was a little muddy in some areas but there were logs put down to step on.  ', 'Muddy sections need some upkeep but this is a favourite I have returned to for 14 years. I don’t have a dog but if you do look out for sharp shale sections on coastline portion of the trail. ', 'went with a group from the Hike NS Summit.  we started out in light rain which made the stretch across Hirtle Beach cobble a bit more tricky than the return when it was dry.  The spring rains and steady use of this trail made it quite muddy when you reach the wooded sections of the trail.  Having said that, my feet stayed dry and there were no big problems.  I believe this will be a great hike on a sunny day as the coastal sections are dramatic.  I did find the cobble a bit annoying and tricky to walk on.  Poles were handy getting around the mud puddles.  This trail is protected by the NS Nature Trust and the Nature Conservancy of Canada and the Kingsburg Trails Assoc?  ', 'Did the hike today. the trail is very wet and muddy ( it rained for like a week) there is alot of roots, so watch your step. the views are still awesome ❤', "love this trail!!! haven't found the secret beach yet, maybe next time.I am going back with in the next 2 weeks.", 'great trail! I would rate it moderate for the uneven terrain  and some muddy bits ', 'A great day with family.  We really enjoyed the trail as well as watching the giant waves coming to shore as we walked along the ocean.', 'Definitely recommend this hike! It was suggested to us while we were visiting the area from Ontario in February. As many others said, the first stretch is along a very rocky beach but when you get to the trail it is well marked and well maintained. Beautiful views of the cliffs and water. We had some icy spots so I imagine other times of the year it could be quite muddy. We took about 2 hours from the parking lot and back with stops for pictures and views.', 'Great trail with beautiful Oceanside views. The first km or so was crazy rocky, so be sure to have boots with good ankle support. Would definitely hike this trail again.', 'A very rewarding hike with excellent ocean views. The first part of the trail crosses an eternity of lose beach rocks on the upper side of the beach. You should wear hiking shoes with ankle support - good place to roll an ankle. If you go in sneakers just be cautious. The trail itself is a loop with over half of it having ocean views. Good for on-leash dogs, however people like to break the rules which is rather annoying... parts of the wooded section of the trail can be extremely muddy but there are stones and boards to walk on to cross. There are also secrets to this trail. Find for yourself. 
This is an area known for high levels of ticks so always practice good after-hike inspections of yourself and your pets. A good dose of the (pet-friendly) Atlantick spray before hiking this area would be recommended. Overall, this is a hike I go back and do every few years as it’s interesting enough to do more than once.', 'Great short hike with rewarding elevation changes, ocean views, a magical forest, and a few secret paths that you should explore. it is not EASY.. the trail requires rugged shoes, is very uneven in places, and the stones on the beach can be very hard to walk along, watch your step.', 'Rocky beach, gorgeous cliff views, alternating terrain, inuksuks, mossy forests, a perfect day hike.', 'Great hike, with amazing views for relatively little effort.  Cobble beach to start, check tides.  Follow loop clockwise for best impact.  Build an inuksuk, swim at a secluded beach.', "this trail begins at a lovely beach with good parking and bathrooms! the water is great for swimming and surfing! 

walking close to the water on softer sand is very comfortable and pleasent! when the shore turns rocky, head to high ground where there is a beaten path. otherwise the round unstable rocks make for a difficult walk for sure!
the terrain has many changes which really make this hike fun and far from boring! great views, places to sit on ground to rest/lunch, explore off trail along shore, break shale to collect Fool's Gold, swimming holes. there is a place to jump about 30' down into a good pool! but it's also a good place to slip off the edge as you are running for the jump, and break your back on the rocks below! this is also a dangerous spot on the hike for kids who struggle with being aware of their surroundings!
if you take your time to enjoy all this little gem has to offer, it is definitely an easy hike for all. any hike can be made difficult if you rush !! 
:)", 'amazing views. the walk to the trail head along the beach on the Sea stones is not fun, but the elevated views from the point are gorgeous.', 'Great trail. The first part along the beach is not the best way to start the trail, as it is quite long and not that beautiful... but lots of different paths and views are amazing ! Also not a lot of people so you get time to enjoy the trail on your own !', 'Beautiful trail. Easily accessible for the whole family. The first portion (the beach) is not representative of all the nice things you can see along the way.', 'Very nice trail with lots of different terrain and great views, it is quite annoying to get to the trail over the lose pebble beach but doesn’t take too long.', 'I did this trail 15 years ago with friends and everything I loved and hated about it then still applies.

Wear very supportive footware. This trail has many different types of terrain and having proper footware is a must.

Try and arrive so that you can use the beach to walk on instead of the ankle rolling pebbles. Check the tide times.

The views are spectacular. The ocean puts on a show at every turn.

Just make sure to leave lots of time, bring lots of water and proper food to sustain you and proper footware!', 'Great day on the trail. Enjoyed with young kids and grandparents. Good for all. Beautiful view and a great place to picnic or enjoy a day at the beach at the end.', 'Beautiful.', 'One of my favorite!', 'Lots of variety for a short hike,  should probably aim for around low tide for the beach bit.', 'This hike starts out on the beach, then meets up with a very well maintained trail! It was foggy when I hiked it, but still a very nice hike.', 'A Beautiful Coastal Trail with a mix of white sand beach, cobblestone shoreline, rocky cliff coastline, mossy meadows and evergreen forests.', 'Beautiful spot, lots of beautiful look out points and not a difficult trail.', 'Beautiful and well worth any trip. Park in the Hirtle Beach car park and run the coast along to Gaff Point. Worth any visit. Well conditioned trail']

['Nice walk with beautiful views!', 'Nice enough, particularly at the end. Recommend doing the loop as mapped. ', 'Beautiful lookouts of the coast and Ingonish island. If you want to do one coastal hike in the park middle head is fantastic', 'We came around 5am to see the sunrise, however, unfortunately it was a foggy and grey day. Trail goes up and down.', 'Did this trail on a hot 30C sunny day with very little ocean breeze.  There are a LOT of ups and downs and rocks and roots to navigate the whole way. ', 'Loved this trail!!! Roots, hills and views!!! Great hike!', 'Super fun hike and amazing views.', 'nice view of the gulf, trail fairly easy


', 'Amazing trail, one of the best in the area. We brought our 5 years old daughter and she was able to walk it completely. The best views ', 'Nice little hike with my honey.', 'What a spectacular view!  The trail wasn’t difficult, but certainly not easy. There are many places to rest and a lot of up and down hills. Lots of bunchberries, blueberries, and juniper. And the drive through the Keltic Lodge area was beautiful. ", 'Great family friendly trail! Amazing ocean views with some ups and downs. After reaching the red chairs if you complete loop instead of going back the same way be prepared for some brush on the trail. Just park at Kentucky Lodge; easy to find ', 'Great hike - lots of ups & downs, but completely worth it - spectacular!!!', 'Very Scenic', 'Nice trail, great views. 
', 'absolutely beautiful, just walked it yesterday  easy trail and worth every second, take all the little paths off to the side you can get really great pics ', 'Be prepared. Part I did was beautiful but part to lodge in park, not in app, had deep snow, no human footprints.", 'Beautiful during all seasons, a must see during the winter! ', "amazing in wintertime! Didn't see anybody. little piece of heaven on earth!
", 'Nicely groomed trail. Great for family walks.', 'Cloudy walk with Ty and Max', 'Easy with a nice payoff.', 'It was beautiful! Can be done fast at a quick pace :)', 'Lovely 2.5 mile loop trail offering a wide variety of gentle up and down terrain and gorgeous water views. Convenient parking at trailhead or at Celtic Lodge Parking Lot. Trail does have some rocky areas and roots - hiking stick helpful!', 'fabulous!']

['Difficult trail with constant steep inclines and declines throughout the trail. We had a dog on leash with us and I wouldn’t recommend if you have a dog that pulls on leash as it can make the steep declines stressful! Beautiful look offs at multiple points along the trail :) We managed to get turned around on ourselves down by Eunice Lake so added an extra couple kms as a result. I notice this mentioned in other reviews too so make sure you continue around to the right of the lake! (If you do the loop where you enter at the 1.7k mark from the main trail)', 'Great trail, difficult hike, a bit overgrown in some areas', 'This has been our favorite trail so far!  ended up 7.5 miles.  it was difficult in the heat but the views and the hike were perfect!  there are several large elevation changes so be prepared for climbing and footing issues.  took us about 3 hours and 15 minutes.  the views!  ', 'well marked but it got long ', 'Lots of ups and downs, the view from the three look-offs are amazing!!', 'Difficult trail, lots of ups and downs. nice views best in autumn!', 'Great trail! I don't recommend bringing poles on this trail as it is very tight and rocky in places. there are plenty of trees and other handholds to use on climbs 
", 'A rough terrain, and some areas of thick overgrowth.  Nice trail for fir adults..', 'Great trail with many look offs. Definitely want to bring the bug spray for this one.', 'A nice difficult trail. Lots of steep inclines, tree roots and rocks but incredible look-offs, a rock formation you can go through along the path, and beautiful lake views.
